Play at one of our two tennis centers where you can take advantage of year-round clinics, youth programs, and private lessons, or check out our neighborhood courts. TENNIS CENTERS MIAMIBEACH FLAMINGO TENNIS CENTER Normal Hours Monday - Thursday 7:30 AM √¢¬Ä¬ì 9 PM Friday - Sunday 7:30 AM √¢¬Ä¬ì 8 PM Map View 305.673.7761 proshop@flamingotenniscenter.com Visit Website BOOK A COURT Register through the tennis center Apple app or website to book a court. Members allowed to book up to 2 days in advance. Non-members are allowed to book 1 day in advance. Sign Up/Login to an Account to Book a Court Download the App | Youth & Adult Programs There are a variety of programs and clinics for all ages offered at this tennis center. Pricing varies by class size and peak hours. View Program Details and Registration | True Beginner Tennis for Women True Beginner Tennis for women is a 4-week program with 7 different skill levels. MIAMIBEACH TENNIS CENTER Normal Hours Monday - Friday: 7:30 AM - 8 PM & Saturday - Sunday: 7:30 AM - 5 PM Map View 305.604.4080 info@mbtennisacademy.com Visit Website Register through the Miami Beach Tennis Center Apple or Android apps to book a court. Download for Apple Devices Download for Android Devices | Adult Tennis Clinics (Year-Round Programs) Registration for all clinics can be made at√Ç www.mbtennisacademy.com/adultclasses √Ç¬†Pricing will range from $25-$35 per person depending on class size and peak hours. | Youth Tennis Programs Pee Wees (Ages 5-7): Wednesdays & Fridays @ 3pm / MTWTHF @ 4pm Register for Pee Wee Programs This one-hour class is designed to introduce tennis as a fun sport to children aged 5-7. Students learn forehands, backhands, and volleys as well as scoring and parts of the court. Quickstart format is used that enables students to learn more control of the ball through the use of low-compression red and orange tennis balls and smaller nets. Aces (Ages 8-12): Mondays & Fridays @ 4PM / Tuesdays & Thursdays @ 5PM Register for Aces Programs This one-hour class is designed to introduce tennis as a fun sport to children aged 8-12. Students learn forehands, backhands, and volleys as well as scoring and parts of the court. Quickstart format is used that enables students to learn more control of the ball through the use of low-compression green tennis balls and full-size nets. Classes are offered every weekday. Junior Academy: This one-hour class is for those who have graduated from recreational tennis and have more stroke control. It is designed to focus on the technique of each of the strokes, as well as learning to sustain a rally from the baseline. 2 days per week is mandatory in order for juniors to get a good level of repetition needed for improvement. Registration for this level is only available for those approved by the head coach.

Forbes contributors publish independent expert analyses and insights. I cover lifestyle, art, and interior design. Follow Author Mar 16, 2021, 03:04pm EDT Apr 05, 2024, 06:19pm EDT Share Save Comment This article is more than 4 years old. The first recorded homes are relics of our human survival within nature. Structures born from necessity, Darwinian‚Äîif you will‚Äîin that the strongest ones kept us alive. If you take the romance we‚Äôve placed on homes today out of the equation, perhaps not much has changed. For most of us, our homes still act as a disconnect from the natural world, separating us by inches of masonry or concrete or brick. Richard Christiansen, however, is not most of us. Christiansen has turned many-a-dream into reality. He‚Äôs founder of the renowned Chandelier Creative agency. He‚Äôs owner of the locally treasured art bookstore Owl Bureau . He took his roots growing up on a farm in the Australian Outback and brought them to the top of a hill in Los Angeles, where he has designed his home as an ode and connection to nature. Today, he‚Äôs turned his artful eye onto the worlds of vegetables and and other earthly pleasures as founder of Flamingo Estate . What started as a passion for growing and harvesting his seven-acre garden, has turned into a pandemic success story and brand of homemade bath and body products, tinctures, candles, fresh flowers, honey, oils, produce, bread, hand sanitizer and more that he plans to put in everyone‚Äôs homes. Richard Christiansen Courtesy of Flamingo Estate As I sat down to talk to Christiansen I‚Äôd imagined a story about a garden. Rather, what I got was a story about love, pleasure, and yes, psilocybin too. A story about how he‚Äôs created Flamingo Estate to bring natural treats back into our lives. Here, he gives insight on how we could all nurture our relationship with nature right at home. Natalie Stoclet: Let‚Äôs start with the Estate itself, what drew you to it? Richard Christiansen: The house has a really interesting history. It was this hedonistic playground on the top of a hill. Back in the 40s and 50s it was a porn studio‚Äîthat part is easy to joke about but it was so much more than that. It was about sexual freedom, a lot of musicians and artists came here, legend has it that party‚Äôs here would go on for days. Back then the studios were not in Hollywood they were in Highland Park, and this was an escape up the hill for a lot of people who wanted a quiet enclave to have some mischief. When I started to understand it‚Äôs history I wanted to bring a lot of its former glory back. I spent years thinking about the house and planting the garden. Flamingo Estate Courtesy of Flamingo Estate MORE FROM FORBES ADVISOR Best High-Yield Savings Accounts Of 2024 By Kevin Payne Contributor Best 5% Interest Savings Accounts of 2024 By Cassidy Horton Contributor NS: How do you design a house in connection to nature? Richard: I designed the house with a company called Studio KO in Paris. We travelled to Morocco and Japan and around Europe. In Morocco, I loved that they made the garden the biggest room of the house. We‚Äôve done that here but have also brought the garden inside. If you close your eyes and walk through the house, your fingertips will feel a lot of different things that are quite sensual. It‚Äôs different textures of raw stone, it‚Äôs a lot of wood. Even though you‚Äôre not in the garden you can walk around my house and feel as if you are in the garden. People get distracted by the way a house looks. It‚Äôs more interesting to think about the way a house feels. NS: When did your home turn into the Flamingo Estate brand? Richard: A year ago this week, my friend‚Äôs farm in LA was about to go bankrupt. All of her vegetables went to restaurants and hotels which halted because of the pandemic. My parents lost their farm when I was a kid so I knew really well what that would feel like. I was not going to let that happen. I told her that we‚Äôd try to sell her vegetables at Owl Bureau, my art bookstore. That very first Friday, we sold 400 boxes. The next Friday we sold 800. And then through various interesting adventures we now have 35 drivers delivering vegetables boxes around the city. We‚Äôve accumulated all sorts of farmers. That‚Äôs how Flamingo Estate as a brand started. Vegetable Boxes by Flamingo Estate Courtesy of Flamingo Estate. NS: What did it mean to brand nature and vegetables? Richard: Before Flamingo Estate, I had all the excuses in the world why I hadn‚Äôt yet created a garden brand like I‚Äôd always wanted. Not enough time, not enough money, not enough people. Decades ago I founded a creative agency, Chandelier Creative, and all of a sudden because of the pandemic, all of the clients we spent 20 years courting and getting to know fell away. I had dozens and dozens of employees who now had nothing to do. Copywriters became in charge of stone fruit management. Art Directors started working on lettuce. It created another outlet for a big group of people who otherwise would have been furloughed. It was interesting to have a bunch of very fashion-forward art directors turn their attention to vegetables. We said that Flamingo Estate was going to be the Herm√®s of vegetables. NS: Beyond produce, how did you start creating Flamingo Estate products from your garden? Richard: I started making my own shampoo and body wash because my water at the estate ran directly into the garden. I didn‚Äôt want my bath water killing my plants. For the first time I realized that some of my favorite brands were full of chemicals. How was I rubbing products on my skin that were unhealthy for my plants? Long before I ever thought we‚Äôd start selling products we made them because we cared about my garden. Now my body wash is full of essential oils. The intention was not to start a brand, it was to save my trees. It‚Äôs just so funny how it all started. Bath Products by Flamingo Estate Courtesy of Flamingo Estate NS: Where did you learn how to cultivate a garden? Richard: I knew about gardening from growing up on my parent‚Äôs farm. But really I‚Äôve just met some wonderful people along the way who gave me their knowledge. An amazing french landscape architect, Arnaud Casaus, did the original master plan for the Flamingo Estate garden. I also have a full-time horticulturist, Jeff Hutchison, as well as a few people who work under him. I just started to have a collection of people around me who are as passionate about nature as I am. NS: What was the first thing you planted when you got the Estate? Richard: My mom and I planted little spigots of rosemary all over a slope. Now it‚Äôs a sea of rosemary down one side of the hill. We also planted a mango tree together on my first Christmas here not long after I bought this place. Now it‚Äôs my official Christmas tree. I think about my parents and Christmas every time I see it sprouting another mango. NS: How many varieties of plants do you have now? Richard: Hundreds. Really. We have hundreds. The garden is seven acres. If people come here I say the only gift I ever want is something I can plant, or a record I can play. Many of my friends will come here with a plant or a tree and it makes me so happy because I can walk around the garden and be surrounded by my friends even when they‚Äôre not here. Flamingo Estate Garden Courtesy of Flamingo Estate. NS: How can those who don‚Äôt have a garden integrate nature into their homes? Richard: Bringing nature inside in any way possible is what keeps my heart racing. Everyone who lives in New York for example has lots of indoor plants, but it‚Äôs also about considering how nature touches your senses. It‚Äôs about bringing nature in for smell and sight and touch and taste. Consider candles, essential oils, bath products, natural materials and colors. NS: What effect do you think bringing nature inside has on our overall well being? Richard: There‚Äôs a lot of healing that can be felt in nature. I often say that mother nature is our best friend and our therapist and our doctor. And it‚Äôs really true. It also doesn‚Äôt require a seven acre garden to do that. It requires a really good hot bath, or a hot shower, and some great essential oils. This past year has made people anxious. People are looking inwards, asking all the right questions, but I think the next frontier is how do we heal with nature. I‚Äôm very excited about psilocybin and magic mushrooms. As we keep speaking of pleasure from the garden as our North Star, when laws change we definitely want to jump into magic mushrooms. Candles by Flamingo Estate Courtesy of Flamingo Estate NS: What resources can we give people who want to create their own earthly paradise? Richard: There are so many good books. One of my favorite books is by Ilse Crawford, she‚Äôs one of my heroes. She pioneered the movement around making a home feel special and not just look special. Her book Home is Where The Heart Is , is an amazing resource for how to make small changes to any space, even if you‚Äôre in a tiny apartment in New York, that makes it feel more warm and loving. It‚Äôs probably my favorite book. NS: What does it mean to brand your home and to live within that brand? Richard: I think anyone whose home feels like a thing of beauty, has probably guarded their choices closely. The first thing is just that edit. I got very diligent in making choices about who I spend my time with, the food we cook, the music we listen to. The fundamental things that bring you pleasure. Pleasure is a human right, and we have become distanced from that. I have created this beautiful garden that I‚Äôve spent years building and I really just wanted to share that with people. I can‚Äôt think of anything I‚Äôd rather do. Flamingo Estate Courtesy of Flamingo Estate. NS: What‚Äôs growing next for Flamingo Estate? Richard: We have a whole bunch of new products coming out. We‚Äôre going to expand our vegetable delivery to New York this year. We‚Äôre meeting different farmers and growers in new cities as we start to really pull that web together. It‚Äôs about connecting these people who grow and make and harvest under one banner that supports what they‚Äôre doing but also has a really clear code of conduct and quality. It gives them another financial platform. Mostly, using all that goodness to cook nice meals and take baths and all that good stuff. Things that are fundamental human pleasures. Miami Beach operates on a commission/city manager form of government. The commission consists of a mayor and six commissioners who serve as the policy-making body of the city. The city manager ensures that policies, directives, resolutions and ordinances adopted by the city commission are enforced and implemented. The city manager is also charged with the daily operations of the city. 

Through fiscal prudence and good leadership, the city‚Äôs journey to excellence is guided by its mission, vision and strategic plan that is making Miami Beach a better place to live, work and play.

With Biscayne Bay to the west and the Atlantic Ocean to the east, the City of Miami Beach is not just a favorite for international and domestic visitors but for a growing residential population too.  The cosmopolitan island city, just 7.1 square miles, is everything that is cool and hot. Flamingo Land owner on life inside the park - and how tragedy left him in charge at just 18 - Hull Live ‚Äå ‚Äå Skip to main content News What's On Football Rugby League More Buy a Paper Funeral Notices Jobs Book an ad Buy a photo Advertise with us Directory Public Notices Newsletter Signup Hull Daily Mail Icon News Hull & East Yorkshire News People Flamingo Land owner on life inside the park - and how tragedy left him in charge at just 18 Gordon Gibb has been in charge of Flamingo Land for more than two decades Comments News Phil Winter Business Editor 07:00, 29 Sep 2018 Losing your father when you‚Äôre just 18 years old must be unthinkably difficult. ‚Äå Imagine at the same time having to take the reins at the family business. And then imagine that very same family business is Flamingo Land. ‚Äå That is exactly what happened to Gordon Gibb, and more than two decades later, the major Yorkshire tourist attraction has gone from strength to strength. ‚Äå Speaking about his arrival into the Flamingo Land business , Mr Gibb said: ‚ÄúIt was a really complex time looking back at the start of my career. ‚ÄúAside from the personal tragedy of losing my best friend, mentor and father, his right-hand man of 30 years died 18 months later at the age of 49. Gordon Gibb, CEO at Flamingo Land ‚Äå ‚ÄúThe loss to the business was immense, but you can't feel sorry for yourself. ‚ÄúIf I'm honest, fear of failure was the strongest motivation, and although we have achieved success along the way, surviving was our first objective.‚Äù Flamingo Land was founded by Mr Gibb‚Äôs father in 1977. ‚Äå READ MORE: Cruel Flamingo Land fraudster conned holidaymakers out of hundreds with 'caravan to rent' Originally called Flamingo Park, the founder bought the company from his employer and changed the name before his death in 1995. Then-18-year-old Gordon Gibb was well and truly thrown in at the deep end but, fast forward to today, and Flamingo Land employs 500 people, turns over ¬£37m and attracts 1.5 million visitors a year. Mr Gibb took the reins at Flamingo Land when he was just 18 ‚Äå Mr Gibb said: ‚ÄúThe biggest challenge over the last two decades has been developing and growing the business without borrowing. ‚ÄúThis was particularly difficult when the economic environment is challenging, but we have managed to deliver a new project every year for our customers as well as breaking some records on the journey, like our record breaking roller coaster, the steepest coaster in the world.‚Äù Mr Gibb has five children ‚Äì aged between 18 months and 13 ‚Äì who are enjoying growing up in and around Flamingo Land and its animals. ‚Äå READ MORE: Terrible Tudors and Awful Egyptians are heading to Hull with Horrible Histories Conservation is a central part of the work Flamingo Land does. Mr Gibb said if it is impossible to properly recreate an animal‚Äôs natural habitat, then it is not kept at the park. Speaking about his children and their futures, the owner said: ‚ÄúOur five children are all too young to consider what career paths their lives may take. More than a million people visit Flamingo Land every year ‚Äå ‚ÄúAll that we want is for them to find their passion. Animal conservation is my passion and I would hope that one of the children carry on my work in this field, but we would never force it on to them.‚Äù READ MORE: How Hull's big attractions helped Yorkshire claim top tourism spot in 2017 Flamingo Land continues to attract more than one million visitors every year, and is a popular destination for families across East Yorkshire. Mr Gibb said the park had ‚Äúcarved a niche out for itself.‚Äù ‚Äå Hull Daily Mail Icon Family news Hull kids absolutely owned Halloween New kids role play centre Magical Santa train Mums already done Christmas shopping He said: ‚ÄúFlamingo Land is unique in that we combine an animal collection, a theme park and a holiday resort within one operation. ‚ÄúWe have carved a niche out for ourselves and have become known for amazing hospitality food and beverage as well as fantastic attractions. ‚Äå ‚ÄúThis is why many customers decide to buy a holiday home on our resort. Being trusted with family days out and holidays is a responsibility which we take very seriously but we are very proud to do so.‚Äù Follow Hull Live Our daily newsletter - To get the latest headlines direct to your email inbox every day, click here . Paddleboards Pavilions Pool Parties Sports Fields Quick Links Events Contact Us FAQs Forms Rules and Regulations Registration Info Senior Events Calendar Does the City of Miami Beach Parks & Recreation have any Summer Camps activities? Expand Yes! The City develops and plans a wide variety of summer programs that appeal to young minds in a fun and positive ways. For commencement dates, please call the Parks and Recreation Department at 305.673.7730 . What's the difference between a Specialty Camp and a Summer Camp? Expand A Specialty Camp places a greater emphasis on a particular sport, craft or activity while a summer camp program incorporates numerous recreational activities into a fun filled full day. Do I need to be a Miami Beach resident to attend the City's camps? Expand No. Non-Resident fees have been established for all Miami Beach programs. How much does it cost to sign up for Summer Day Camp? Expand Visit our summer camp and specialty camp webpages for the latest camp fees or call 305.673.7730 for more information. Do you offer any programs for people with disabilities? Expand Yes! The City of Miami Beach strives to make all of our programs accessible to all who wish to participate, including, but not limited to, inclusion into recreation-which allows children with disabilities to participate alongside children without disabilities in recreational programs. Recreational programs for adults are also available. Please contact the ADA Coordinator Cindy Casanova at 305.673.7730 more information. Visit the Special Abilities and Inclusion Program Page for more information > What other options are available if I cannot afford to pay for my child to attend Summer Camp? Expand Financial Assistance is available for After School Programs and Summer Camp for qualified Miami Beach residents. To be considered for Financial Aid, you must submit a complete registration and scholarship packet. Some restrictions apply. Documentation may be required. Call 305.673.7730 for more information. Does the City offer a discount on the Summer Camp if more than one child is registered? Expand Yes! A 50% discount is applied for each additional Miami Beach resident√Ç¬†sibling for the summer camp program. What type of activities does the After School Program offer the kids? Expand A score of games and activities such as kickball, soccer, tails, arts & crafts, homework assistance and others, are provided on a daily basis. Who is considered a Miami Beach Resident? Expand The city limits are from 1 st √Ç¬†street to 86 th √Ç¬†street. Please visit our√Ç Residency Requirements √Ç¬†webpage to inquire about√Ç¬†any documents needed in order to enroll in our programs at resident rate.√Ç¬†We may require additional documentation. What paperwork do I need to bring in to qualify for a scholarship? Could there be more I need to provide after I make the application? Expand Applicant must be a City of Miami Beach Resident. Please visit our√Ç Residency Requirements √Ç¬†webpage to inquire about any documents needed in order to enroll in our programs at resident rate.√Ç¬†Applicants must also fill out a financial aid application and submit income verification such as income tax, section 8 subsidy, Medicaid, food stamps or any other government assistance. The City reserves the right to require additional documentation, when appropriate. Do your pools have an accessible lift? Expand Yes! Flamingo Park Pool, the Scott Rakow Youth Center, and Normandy Isle Pool all have accessible lifts. Please call ahead if possible; Flamingo: 305.673.7750 , Scott Rakow: 305.673.7200 , Normandy: 305.993.2021. Does the City have beach wheelchairs? Expand The City of Miami Beach offers manual "Beach wheelchairs" for those who are mobility impaired, to enjoy our beautiful beaches.√Ç¬†Please follow these recommendations for making your surf chair experience more enjoyable: Call ahead 305.673.7000 ext. 7714. It is on a first come, first serve basis from 9:00 am √¢¬Ä¬ì 5:00 pm. Bring a friend for assistance. Beach wheelchairs are not self-propelled and City staff are not able to provide assistance with transferring into or pushing you in the chair. Keep track of time. Staff must store the chairs before they leave each day. Chairs must be returned by 5:00 pm. Leave a deposit. There is no charge to use the Beach wheelchairs, but you may be asked to leave something of value, (drivers license, wheelchair, photo ID, etc.) to ensure that the chair will be returned. Be careful. The Beach wheelchair can go into the water no more 6√¢¬Ä¬ù deep because the wheels are very buoyant, so stay near the shoreline. However, the electric chairs cannot go into the water. Mobi-Mats are a safe beach access surface for those who are mobility impairs to reach our beautiful beaches. Locations: South of 1st, 3rd, 5th, 6th, 8th, 10th, 14th, 15th, Lincoln Road, 17th, 19th, 64th, 69th, 72nd, 74th, and 79th Street. Keep us posted. Let us know how we can improve our access to people with disabilities. Please call our ADA coordinator, Cindy Casanova with suggestions at 305.673.7730 . Beach wheelchair locations: 1001 Ocean Drive and South Pointe Park (1st Street). Does the City have any Dog Parks? Expand Yes! Please visit our√Ç Bark Parks √Ç¬†webpage for more information. How long is financial aid good for? Expand Financial Aid forms must be filled out for Summer Camp and/or the beginning of our After School Program. Financial Aid approved for After School is good from the end of August √¢¬Ä¬ì the end of the summer. Does the City offer any programs for adults? Expand Absolutely! Adult programs vary throughout the season. Some of our adult programs include: Tennis, Swimming, Computer Classes, Senior Scenes and Athletic Leagues. Please contact the Parks and Recreation Department at 305.673.7730 or click√Ç Adult Programs √Ç¬† or√Ç Senior Programs √Ç¬†for more information. Does the City rent facilities and what are the requirements to rent one? Expand Yes, we offer a wide selection of facilities for rental from a park pavilion to an entire youth center! Rental fees are based on the facility selected and must include City staff. For a list of facilities available please visit our website√Ç rental page , visit our facilities or call 305.673.7730 . When is the Recreation Review published? Expand The Recreation Review is published annually to highlight Miami Beach summer camp offerings. It is mailed to all families with children in Miami Beach. In addition, the City's MB Magazine is mailed quarterly to every household in Miami Beach and includes year-round updates on Parks and Recreation programs. For a copy of the Recreation Review, please click here. Does the City have recreation programs for 3 & 4 year olds? Expand The City of Miami Beach Parks and Recreation Department currently offers a Playtime program for children ages 3-4. This program includes dancing, singing, arts and crafts, guest appearances and some academics Monday through Friday 9:00 am - 1:00 pm. Class size is limited. Please visit our√Ç¬†Toddler Programs webpage for more information. We also offer swimming classes, art classes and much more. Please contact the Parks and Recreation Department at 305.673.7730 for more information. Can I rent a park /playground or facility from the Parks and Recreation Department? Expand Yes! We have many locations for rentals and birthday parties. Click here for the rental page √Ç¬†or please call 305.673.7730 or visit our facilities. Is there a fee to join the After school program? Expand Please visit our After School page for the latest fee information. Financial Aid√Ç¬†is available for qualified city residents. Do you have an Adopt a Tree Program? Expand The City of Miami Beach currently does not have one however; Miami-Dade County does have an Adopt-a-Tree Program.√Ç Click here for more√Ç information > Can I make a donation to the Parks and Recreation Department? Expand For sponsorship donations contact the Marketing & Communications Department by calling 305.673.7000 ext. 7575. Do residents get preferred rates at city facilities, including the golf courses & recreation programs? Expand We have preferred resident rates for all programs in the Parks and Recreation Department. All fees are quoted per program series or activity. Please call 305.673.7730 for more information. Can I register, find information, or make a tee time on-Line for the Miami Beach Golf Club? Expand The√Ç Miami Beach Golf Club √Ç¬†has designated policies to accommodate a smooth and fast tee time booking for on-line users. Please visit√Ç Miami Beach Golf Club √Ç¬†√Ç¬†or call our pro-shop at 305.532.3350 to book now!√Ç¬†The√Ç Normandy Shores Golf Club √Ç¬†is also available for play. Please call 305.868.6502 . What other services are offered at the Miami Beach Golf Club and the Normandy Shores Golf Club? Expand Both golf clubs are√Ç¬†full service. Golf lessons are available from our PGA certified professionals in a group or individual.√Ç¬†Please visit the√Ç Miami Beach Golf Club √Ç¬†web page or the√Ç Normandy Shores Golf Club √Ç¬†web page for more information. Can anyone use the Youth Centers all day- any day? Expand The Scott Rakow Youth Center and North Shore Park Youth Center are open Mondays √¢¬Ä¬ì Fridays for registered After School participants. The Scott Rakow Youth Center caters to children grades 4 th √Ç¬†- 12 th√Ç and the North Shore Park Youth Center caters to children grades K - 5 th √Ç¬†from 2:00 pm √¢¬Ä¬ì 6:00 pm. For more information on our hours of operation for√Ç¬†the youth centers please visit the√Ç¬†√Ç¬†Scott Rakow Youth Center√Ç¬†√Ç¬†or√Ç¬†√Ç¬†North Shore Park & Youth Center√Ç¬†. Who do I call to reserve a field or open space? Expand To reserve a field or open space email√Ç devaughnchristopher@miamibeachfl.gov . Are Tennis private lessons allowed at neighborhood parks? Expand No! Outside contractors cannot utilize city facilities for profit.√Ç¬† Report unauthorized lessons to 305.673.7730. Do you provide transportation from schools for your After School programs? Expand Free transportation is provided for after school registered participants from the following school sites: Biscayne, Treasure Island, South Pointe, Fienberg Fisher, Mater Beach and North Beach Elementary Schools, Nautilus Middle School and Miami Beach Senior High on all school days. Transportation is provided ONLY from designated pick up sites to their neighborhood facilities. Do you provide transportation to your sports leagues? Expand We do not offer transportation to our intramural sport leagues. For more information please call 305.673.7730 . Can anyone join the swim team? Expand Please call 305.673.7750 , visit our√Ç Aquatics √Ç¬†webpage√Ç¬†or email pdimuont@miamibeachfl.gov for more information. Is a child with disabilities allowed to participate in your programs? Expand Inclusion in Recreation enables children with disabilities to participate in regularly scheduled recreational activities including after school programs, athletics, and more at the following locations: Scott Rakow Youth Center, North Shore Park Youth Center, Normandy Isle, and the Flamingo Park at the Police Athletic League. Do you have Senior programs? Expand Yes! The √¢¬Ä¬úSenior Scenes√¢¬Ä¬ù program which is designed for senior citizens, has recently regained popularity due to the introduction of new classes such as Fine Arts & Painting, Yoga and Chair Aerobics. Please visit or√Ç Senior Programs √Ç¬†Page√Ç¬†for a detailed list of our programs or call 305.861.3616 for more information. Are Golf private lessons given at the Miami Beach Golf club? Expand Yes! We do offer private lessons at the Miami Beach Golf Club. Please contact Steve Farrell, Director of Golf at 305.532.3350 for more information. Can I remove a tree from the swale? Expand No! Residents are required to pull a permit to transplant, prune, relocate or remove any tree from a swale in the City. An application form acquired from the Public Works Department, which will act as the lead agency is required. The completed application will then be processed through the Planning Department, Parks Maintenance, Environmental Resource Management Division and Parking Departments for further review. To obtain a permit a $25 application fee is required payable to the City. Please call Public Works at 305.673.7620 for more information. Who maintains the causeways into the City? Expand The Greenspace Division manages the causeway with a full service landscape service to the public. Please call 305.673.7720 for more information. How can I get a job with your Department? Expand Human Resources mission is to locate and hire the most qualified applicants, while serving the total needs of all employees. Please visit√Ç¬†√Ç Human Resources √Ç¬†√Ç¬†for our list of current job openings. You can now√Ç apply online √Ç¬†by clicking on the job title you are interested in and then submitting your application electronically!. Who do I contact in order to have a special event in the city? Expand Please visit our√Ç special events √Ç¬†page for information regarding√Ç¬†special events, weddings/ceremonies, demonstrations, banners & billboards, event locations and more. How do the new participation membership for recreation programs work? For how long is each card valid? Expand Membership is designed to eliminate parents from filling out the same paperwork repeatedly for each program/location with the exception of certain paperwork such as the emergency contact information, field trip forms, etc. This will expedite the whole registration process. Employees may still ask to verify proof of residency.√Ç¬† Memberships are valid for 2 years from the beginning of the Fall through the end of the Summer (ex. Fall 2019 - Summer 2021). Social Impact We Support Since launching in 2018, Flamingo has supported and donated to nonprofit organizations that work to ensure women build healthy relationships with their bodies. Through a commitment to education and healing we hold our brand promise to champion women and their bodies. How We Do It Education: We work with partners to create open dialogue and easier access to information that has historically been taboo or gatekept from women about their bodies‚Äîbecause we know that getting access to accurate information about women's bodies is not easy. Healing: We support partners who are helping women to address their body trauma, mindset, and well-being because we believe that emotional healing is an important step to having a healthy relationship with your body. Girl Scouts mission is to build girls of courage, confidence and character who make the world a better place. Girl Scouts and Flamingo are embarking on a two-year partnership to learn what girls need to develop a healthy relationship with their bodies. Together, we will create a program for Girl Scouts that addresses important topics like body confidence. Exhale to Inhale uses trauma informed yoga to empower survivors of sexual and domestic violence and help communities develop skills and knowledge to support them. With our support of the scholarship training program, Exhale to Inhale has trained over 265 individuals with a focus on equity, access and representation, creating pathways for healing for thousands more survivors this year. Black Girls Smile provides gender-responsive and culturally-affirming mental wellness education, resources, and support geared toward Black women and girls. In partnership with Flamingo, BGS will provide education and opportunities for community building through their Intersectionality Workshop series, helping BGS reach 2,000 Black women and girls this year. Girls on the Run (GOTR) inspires girls to be joyful, healthy and confident using a fun, experience-based curriculum that creatively integrates running. With Flamingo‚Äôs support, GOTR will develop and launch an enhanced suite of curricula to help participants recognize their inner strength, build confidence, and centers key social-emotional learning themes. The new curricula will be released across their network of 171+ councils, reaching an estimated 200,000 girls through 50,000 trained volunteer coaches. AAKOMA believes that to meet the mental health needs of Youth of Color, we need to operate at three levels: raising consciousness, providing accessible tools, and changing systems to provide better care. With our support, AAKOMA will provide nearly 350 hours of free virtual therapy to intersectionally diverse Young People of Color (including young people who identify as LGBTQAI+ and those with disabilities) with a special focus on African American and Black women/femmes. With our support The Alliance will add 2 new free, weekly clinician-led support groups to expand access to effective, data-driven care: one specifically tailored for and by the BIPOC community and another for individuals in mid-life and beyond. As part of the partnership, The Alliance will also study the impact of these groups, ensuring there will be more robust data sets that shed light on this important issue going forward.
